Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.As the anniversary of the battle of St Valéry-en-Caux approaches, an international search has been launched to uncover the identity of a fallen hero.The soldier of the st Highland Division evaded capture during the infamous Second World War battle, in which almost  men from Kintyre fought, but would later be discovered and now rests in an unnamed grave.Days after the mass evacuations at Dunkirk, thousands of men from the st Highland Division remained on mainland Europe supporting their French allies. As German troops advanced through Normandy, the st fought valiantly, protecting French citizens, hoping evacuation by sea would be forthcoming.On June  , German tanks surrounded the ision at the French fishing port of St Valéry. This, alongside a curtain of heavy fog, made the long-awaited flotilla rescue unviable and they were forced to surrender. Those who were not killed in the fighting were captured as prisoners of war and marched to camps in Eastern Europe, where they remained for five gruelling years.Following the commemorations to mark the th anniversary of the battle last June, a remarkable story has emerged. One brave soldier miraculously evaded capture and was taken in by a French family who hid him from the occupying German forces.#We were contacted by Monsieur Patrick Prieur, a -year-old St Valéry resident whose grandparents and father remained in the town during the entirety of the war. He told us the story of the escapee and the tragedy that befell him,# said Dr Claire Armstrong, chief executive of Legion Scotland.#As we approach the st anniversary of the battle, we hope to identy this Scottish hero, give him the recognition he deserves and bring peace to his family.#Patrick Prieur recalled the tale his late father told him: #A soldier from the st Highland Division was hidden by a family in the village. They bonded and the family learned he was a married man with a we and two daughters waiting for him tohome.#For several weeks, the soldier remained hidden but, regretfully, he was eventually discovered by German troops and marched through the town to the municipal cemetery.#After being forced to dig his own grave, he was positioned against the cemetery wall and shot. His death deeply upset the townspeople, who had been aware of his hiding, and especially my father, who was only  at the time.#In later years, the Franco-British military cemetery was built and his body was moved there. His grave is marked as #Known unto God# and my father and other villagers tended to it for decades after the war ended.#Monsieur Prieur added: #My father had been gted a piece of paper on which the soldier#s name was written, #Keller Len Scott#, and this became his prized possession. He desperately wanted to find the soldier#s family to tell them what had happened to their beloved and where he was laid to rest, but having very little information, he struggled.#In  my father passed away and, being eager to finish what he started, I recently contacted Poppyscotland and the Highland Reserve Forces# and Cadets# Association to ask for help.#Michelle McKearnon, head of engagement at the Highland Reserve Forces# and Cadets# Association, said: #We started to do our own research to unearth the fallen soldier#s identity but only got so far. We believe the name order on the piece of paper may have been written in military fashion, with the surname preceding any given names, so the family name might be Keller.#We#re now at an impasse, struggling to find additional information through our own resources, so we need the knowledge of the wider community to continue our efforts.#Dr Armstrong added: #We are urging anyone who believes they know of or has any information about our #Unknown Soldier#, no matter how small, to get in touch.#This brave man fought valiantly for his country and to repay our debt to him for his service would be an honour, not only for Legion Scotland as custodians of remembrance, but for his family, Monsieur Prieur#s father, the people of St Valéry and, ultimately, for all the #unknown soldiers# who sacriced their lives for us.#Anyone with information that could help identy the soldier should visit poppyscotland.org.uk stvalery

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.A classic British racing yacht and her crew were saved from being dashed onto the rocks of the Mull of Kintyre on Saturday night by Campbeltown#s leboats during a six-hour rescue operation.The yacht was competing in the Scottish Islands Peak Race.The rudder of the ft-long Sceptre had broken and Force Six winds from the northwest were driving her onto clfs below the lighthouse.Campbeltown#s Severn-class leboat was launched with the inshore leboat following. They did notto the harbour until after pm with the casualty in tow.The following day, Sceptre skipper Tom Smith praised the hard work and efficiency of the Campbeltown leboat crews.Diver Robert Lamont, a member of the leboat crew the night before, went in and removed the damaged rudder ready for Sceptre to be towed by tug to Troon, the finish of the race.The race sails from Oban to Mull, Jura and Arran then Troon, stopping at each island for a team of runners to complete a hill race.Sceptre, with a crew of four, was carrying the boys# team from Glenalmond School, Perth.She had run aground the night before entering Craighouse, Jura. Everything looked fine on the yacht, which was built in Argyll at Alexander Robertson#s Holy Loch yard to compete in the America#s Cup of .#As a precaution, we did not have the boys on board for the tough leg round the Mull of Kintyre to Arran,# said crew member Roger Finbow.#They haven#t missed the race they were on board Blue Damsel, carrying the girls# team.#The decision proved a wise move as not only did the rudder come loose leaving the yacht with no steering, it was flapping wildly and in danger of damaging the hull.As a precaution, the leboat crew put a heavy-duty pump on board but this was not needed.HMS Dragon broke off her sea trials to come to the aid of Sceptre. The Type  Clyde-built destroyer stood by until the leboat arrived.TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOCalls were mounting earlier this week for a Scottish Office decision on the proposed ferry link between Campbeltown and Northern Ireland.The Scottish Office has been considering a business plan for state-owned Caledonian MacBrayne to operate the link with Ballycastle in Northern Ireland since the beginning of February.The company needs Scottish Office permission to become involved in the project.But concern is growing that unless a decision is made soon the necessary harbour work at Campbeltown will not start until it is too late for the service to begin next year.Two Campbeltown ambulance men were among six from Argyll recently presented with long service and good conduct medals by the Duke of Argyll.Ronnie Hamilton and Malcolm Black travelled to Oban for the presentation, carried out by the Duke on behalf of HM Queen.The medals are not awarded automatically but are made on the recommendation of a special .The Duke told the ambulance men: #What you do is not a profession, it is a vocation.#He also paid tribute to their families, pointing out the ambulance men worked anti-social hours for long periods at a time.FIFTY YEARS AGOCampbeltown was #switched on# to colour television on Tuesday by the town#s new Provost, William Craig, in his first official engagement.The service has been brought to Campbeltown by Redfusion, the firm which pipes television to several thousand subscribers from its mast at Crosshill Farm.The firm#s Scottish general manager Mr Colin Payne said that Redfusion offers a public service of which they were proud.#We looked at the television problems here. There were just BBC and STV and occasionally Ulster in the town.#We said can we bring to Campbeltown the full range of colour programmes which are available where and the answer to that was #yes#.#There are now six programmes on the system. There aren#t many places in the country which can receive this.#ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOAn English steam liner which called in here for bait one day last week had full bunkers and a plentul reserve of coal in ious corners. She had gone to Ostende for the fuel.A further restriction of the gas supply in the burgh comes into force on Saturday night. The hours during which there will be reduced and normal pressure respectively are given in advertisement.The local branch of the Miners# Union opened a subscription list this week for the purpose of starting a communal soup kitchen. It is not intended, of course, to confine the benefits of the scheme to miners or their dependents. Over £ has already been raised and the committee intend to publish the list of subscriptions next week.A welcome break in our comparative isolation from the mainland was made at the beginning of the week when the steamer Kinloch made a special run to the upper reaches, with mail, passengers and cargo.Many merchants, not only in Campbeltown but at Carradale and the west of Arran ports, were carrying very low stocks and this run was not made a day too soon to prevent absolute scarcity of not a few necessities.Flour, for one thing, was running very short, and the new supplies got by bakers were very much-needed.Alcohol is again tipped as a likely rival to petrol. The new motor fuel is being produced by the Distillers Company Ltd and consists of a mixture of  per cent of alcohol,  per cent of benzole and  per cent of paraffin. The idea of using alcohol is not new, but a fatal obstacle has been the unwillingness of the government to release its hold upon alcohol and permit it to be used for commercial purposes.

story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I have been reading a lot of reports and letters in national and local newspapers about the problems experienced at the Rest and Be Thankful.I have no doubt that those charged with keeping the trunk road operational and safe for drivers are doing their best in the circumstances.However, there now seems to be an acceptance in Transport Scotland that a new solution has to be found.In a letter to the press, George Allan points out that the -mile route from Strathlachlan to Colintraive and the eight miles between Ormidale and Tighnabruaich were designed and constructed in  or  years.I was a member of the survey and design team on these routes. I was also involved in the construction of  miles of the A between Perth and Inverness in  years. These civil engineering schemes demonstrate what can be achieved when there is real political will and commitment to prioritise projects.I realise Transport Scotland has its own procedures for appointing consultants for the design processes and there are detailed environmental impact assessments to be done. It does, however, seem to me that its programming of the Rest and Be Thankful improvement is completely lacking in ambition.As a former director of roads and transport in Highland, perhaps I may be permitted to comment on the long-term solution.I would saythere are no geological features found on the other side of the glen which will cause a repeat of current problems, then the construction of a new road in ersion would cause less disruption to traffic than trying to form landslip shelters or tunnels adjacent to the existing carriageway.The main thing though is for Transport Scotland and their political masters to just get on with it.This week, Scotland#s Charity Air Ambulancemarks its eighth anniversary – after a year like no other.Throughout the coronavirus pandemic, our Helimed crews have never missed a beat maintaining our emergency helicopter air ambulance service across Scotland#s mainland and island communities. In fact we#ve enhanced our service with the launch of a new aircraft – Helimed  in Aberdeen last year – which has already had a huge impact on pre-hospital care in the Grampian, Highland and island regions.In our busiest year ever, our aircrew have endured challenging working conditions, with additional procedures and cumbersome protective and safety equipment as they go about an already dficult and stressful job.But they#re not complaining – this is what the Scottish public ask of them, to save and improve lives, wherever the need arises, and they fulfil their role with courage and pride.Our exemplary performance during this national crisis has been a tribute to how far SCAA has come in just eight years and I, for one, am immensely proud of what the SCAA team has achieved.But our operational teams are acutely aware that we are only able to provide this critical service, thanks to the continued public donations which you have maintained throughout these dficult times. So you are the real heroes in our charity.SCAA is the people#s helicopter – funded by the people of Scotland, for the people of Scotland – and our two frontline aircraft are stood by ready to help you, your family, your friends, colleagues, neighbours or anyone in your community when you most need us.As we mark our eighth birthday on May , we are asking the people of Scotland,they can, to support us into the future. Any donation, however small, to celebrate our anniversary will help to save a le – just like the numerous lives we have already saved over almost , missions.SCAA vows to continue to transform emergency care in Scotland, particularly to our rural and island communities, with your support. Thank you.As a coalition of leading providers of care and support to vulnerable children and young people, we congratulate all MSPs on their election and welcome the consensus there is between the major political parties to tackle the growing mental health crisis in our young people.We have for some time raised concerns over a potential lost generation of vulnerable children and young people, whose mental health is being impacted even further by the Covid- pandemic.There have been dramatically increased waiting times for mental health treatment during lockdown.In December , for example,  per cent of children and young people had been waiting more than a year for specialist treatment, compared with . per cent in , a truly frightening statistic.A commitment by MSPs to focus on mental health, increasing investment in support services and intervention strategies, must be a priority for this parliament, giving our young people the care and support they need, when they need it.The frightening statistics on the deteriorating mental health of many young people presents a compelling case for a radical new plan for our struggling mental health services and for a national crusade to address what is a mental health pandemic, underpinned by considerably greater resourcing.This is a crisis we can overcome, but it will require a similar energy and commitment to that demonstrated for Covid-we are to achieve this and prevent many young people giving up on their futures.At sight loss charity RNIB Scotland, we are concerned the Covid- crisis might have impacted on people who are blind and partially sighted, many of whom are older.We would like to highlight the emotional reassurance and practical help we offer during the coronavirus lockdown and its aftermath.Covid has eclipsed all other health news in the past year but  people still start to lose their sight in Scotland every week. Add to that stress over Covid and the lockdowns and there could be more people needing support and reassurance.Our Need to Talk telephone counselling service remains available in Argyll and Bute and the Western Highlands for anyone diagnosed with sight loss, as well as families, friends and carers.Losing your sight can be devastating news to take in. But our trained helpers can support you in coming to terms with your condition and finding the way forward.The uncertainty during the Covid lockdown over access to basic shopping and medication, a lack of information in accessible formats, the social isolation, the barriers to being guided because of social distancing # these have all added to and compounded the mental and emotional stress people are experiencing.But we want people with sight loss to know they are not alone and that help is available.To contact the Need to Talk service, phone the RNIB Helpline on    or email needtotalk@rnib.org.uk

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.And yet…One night in the s, a young British student felt compelled to get up and pray for #Irina#. She had no idea who that was. A year later in London she met the Russian poet Irina Ratushinskaya, released from a labour camp in the USSR where she had been imprisoned for her Christian faith.Denied paper, she wrote poems on soap bars. In one poem she wrote:Believe me, it was often thus:I have never forgotten that extraordinary poem. How far can kindness reach In Mid Argyll there is a group of people who offer prayers for anyone who asks. You don#t have to be #religious# – whatever that means – to ask. You can ask for yourself or someone . It can be something huge, or something ordinary. title: former-ross-high-pupil-ruari-paton-aiming-scottish-cup-glory
story: Ruari Paton will be hoping to line up for Stranraer todaywhen they make the long journey north to face Brora Rangers, who stunned Hearts in the previous round.The frontman attended the Tranent secondary school after signing for Hibernian as a teenager and making the move from Dublin.Many had expected Stranraer to be travelling to Tynecastle this weekend but Brora caused one of the biggest shocks in the competitionrsquos history when they won - last Tuesday.Paton was part of the Stranraer team taking on Brechin City at the same time and said that his reaction was much the same as football fans up and down the country when he heard the result.He said: ldquoI would not like to take anything away from Brora but you donrsquot really hear of a Championship team getting beaten by a Highland League or a Lowland League team ever.ldquoIt was a shock, it was a big shock, but fair play to them.ldquoWhat an achievement it is and it is an amazing challenge to overcome.ldquoYou cannot take anything away from them.Stranraer have enjoyed an impressive start to the campaign, with just one defeat since the beginning of November, as they look toto League One.Paton, who now lives in Bothwell, South Lanarkshire, has been at the heart of that form, scoring eight goals in all competitions, with strikes against Spartans and a last-minute penalty winner against Kelty Hearts in the previous round.He has also found the net for Gala Fairydean Rovers, while on loan from Hibs, and for East Kilbride in the competition last year.Now, attention has turned to the trip to Brora and Paton said: ldquoTherersquos nothing better in the world than scoring. Any forward player will tell you that. If you have a terrible game and score a goal or play fantastic and not score ndash you are judged on your goals as a forward.ldquoHopefully, I will get another goal but I need to make sure I am in the team. I would love another goal and I love the Scottish Cup. I loved it with East Kilbride and Gala Fairydean Rovers ndash it is great and you love those big moments in competitions.Paton moved from Dublin to East Lothian after signing for Hibs around his th birthday.He lived with Helen Leslie and her two sons, Darren and Jonathan, off Tranentrsquos Waterloo Road and attended Ross High School, where he studied physical education, English and sports leadership.The striker was quick to praise both the family and the school for helping him develop. He said: ldquoThey took me in asI was part of their family.ldquoThey were absolutely fantastic to me and made me feel so welcome.ldquoI went for dinner with them and they were brilliant.ldquoIn my first year, I spoke to Sean McPartlin, education and welfare officer, and he askedI wanted to do something. I agreed to it and they said I would train some days.ldquoIt is the best thing I ever did.That saw Paton ide his time between attending school and training at Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains on the outskirts of Ormiston.The -year-old spent two years at the secondary school and told Courier Sport how much he enjoyed the experience. He added: ldquoIt was brilliant ndash the best thing I ever did, honestly.ldquoI was not too keen going to school at that age with football andI had not then I would not have made many friends. The amount of people I met through school was unbelievable.Paul Reynolds, headteacher of the Tranent secondary school, said: ldquoNot only was Ruari a standout footballer, he was a true gentleman.ldquoHe was always extremely polite and his positive attitude was infectious. I have rarely met someone so filled with optimism.ldquoWith his lsquogo get lsquoemrsquo attitude, he settled into Ross High School very quickly and it was a pleasure to have him here. Irsquom delighted to hear that he is still playing and wish him all the very best.

title: bbcs-money-nothing-salvages-items-kinwegar-recycling-centre-wallyford
story: Salvage superhero Sarah Moore was at the East Lothian Council-run site at Kinwegar recently to pick up unwanted goods, give them a new lease of le and turn them into cash for their original owners.The presenter spoke to three East Lothian men ndash two from Musselburgh and one from Elphinstone ndash who arrived at the skips to dispose of the three items.They were delighted to hand them over to her and appear on the programme, which was aired on BBC last month.Michael Clague, the owner of the four-man tent, from Musselburgh, said it was ldquopast its use-by date.He said: ldquoIrsquom just glad the tent is going to be recycled as it was sitting in our garage for some time.Sarah took it to award-winning bag maker Neil Wragg, who turned the old tent into  tote bags, which were sold to people all over the country via social media.Sarah visited the Honest Toun to hand over pound to Michael, who said he would use the cash for a homecoming for his son, who was at sea, and donate some to the Tranent-based Walk with Scott Foundation to help with its charity work.Another Musselburgh man, Alan, was getting ready to throw away a glass-topped coffee table. He and his partner felt it might not now be safe with grandchildren around the house.Sarah took the ldquoretro restoration project to East London-based, award-winning wallpaper, textile and surface designer Daniel Heath, who transformed the table with a custom screenprint design, and spray etch pattern on new toughened glass.Sarah again visited the original owner at his home in Musselburgh to hand over pound profit after the tablersquos sale to a furniture and interior shop in Northumberland. Alan said he planned to treat his grandchildren to a day out with the money he received.An old miniature greenhouse, brought to the centre by George, from Elphinstone, and believed to be an lsquoapprenticersquo piece dating from the s, was rescued to be worked on by Sarah herself at her West Sussex base.ldquoItrsquos a shame to put it in the skip but Irsquom trying to clear out, George said.Sarah went on to turn it into ldquoa vintage greenhouse with a bit of quirkiness by adding new panes of clear and coloured perspex to create a stained glass effect. She filled the fully al greenhouse with plants, selling it to a private buyer via social media.Back at his home in Elphinstone, a delighted George received pound from the sale, which he planned to give to his two sons.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe were very pleased that the programme chose to visit our recycling centre, which provides a valuable service to local residents.The programme can be viewed at bbc programmes mvl

title: east-lothians-jamie-ramsay-cycling-across-uk-80-days-drum-support-olympics
story: Jamie Ramsay had planned to travel to the international showcase last year, cycling and sailing the whole way from London to Tokyo.But the coronavirus pandemic saw the event pushed back  months, with Jamie, from Whittingehame, now going on a journey with a dference.It will see him complete  days of socially distanced cycling around the UK through June and July.The -year-old, sponsored by Whole Earth , said: ldquoIrsquom disappointed not to be able to go the whole way to Japan but am really looking forward to meeting fellow Team GB supporters in Scotland and around Britain.ldquoWersquore all in this pandemic together and need a bit of fun. I hope my passion and determination to do this challenge will get people in Scotland behind our Team GB heroes and show the benefits of exercise and nutrition on positive mental attitude and wellbeing.The journey will take Jamie ndash who has previously cycled from Sao Paulo in Brazil to Boliviarsquos La Paz, and run from Vancouver in Canada to Argentinarsquos capital city Buenos Aires ndash around Britain.The former Belhaven Hill, Stenton Primary and Loretto School pupil will pass through towns and cities twinned with or named after places along his original route, including Moscow in East Ayrshire and Holland in Hampshire.Instead of ending up in Tokyo, he will be crossing the finishing line in lsquoStokeyorsquo, also known as Stoke-on-Trent.Visiting Team GB athletesrsquo families, schools and fans en route, Jamie will record their cheers and waves on doorsteps, creating the biggest virtual Mexican wave to spur on Team GB hopefuls.His gruelling challenge will also see him climb Ben Nevis, cycle Hadrianrsquos Wall, and swim the Blue Lagoon in Abereiddy in south-west Wales.Last Tuesday, two-time Olympic rowing champion Helen Glover fired the starting gun from Londonrsquos  Queen Elizabeth Park to signal the start of Jamiersquos journey.Helen, who is aiming for a hat-trick of Olympic gold medals when the Games get under way in July, said: ldquoOur fans mean everything to us but wersquore now facing a Games this summer with no British spectators in Tokyo.ldquoJamiersquos epic journey to help get fans behind us is awe-inspiring. We have so much respect for his perseverance and hope hersquoll spur us on to bring gold home for our fans this summer.Follow Jamiersquos progress at wholeearthfoods teamgb wholewayjourney

title: new-use-approved-former-mens-club-haddington
story: East Lothian Property has been given approval to make the changes in the former Haddington Recreation Club, which closed its doors more than  years ago.The office would be created on the ground floor of the Sidegate building, with a two-bedroom flat created on both the first and second floors.The developer said: ldquoWe are keen to preserve this historic building forming an important part of the Haddington townscape."Our proposals will provide a viable way to maintain and preserve this historic property.No members of the public registered an objection to the plans.The planning officerrsquos report reads: ldquoThe proposed change of use to offices and two flats would not result in signicant harm to the amenity of the area, including the amenity of neighbouring properties."Future occupants of the proposed flats would benefit from privacy and amenity.

title: modern-day-makeover-historic-ormiston-footpath
story: The path, known locally as Clarty Loan, links Park Road and Limeylands Road.It was once used by coal miners on their way to and from work at the four mines surrounding the village.It is now used by local residents as a shortcut to the local shops, park and primary school, and is also seen as a safe route since it is not suitable for vehicles.With new homes being built in and around Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association suggested that upgrading the path would be of great benefit to the local community and area.Walker Homes, which is building properties in the west of the village, agreed to fund the reinstatement of the path and pay East Lothian Council to do so.The improvement works consist of new lighting along the walkway.The issue of lighting along Clarty Loan was raised with the local housing partnership at East Lothian Council, which agreed to fund light installation.Mark Ormiston, Ormiston West Tenants and Residents Association chairman, said: ldquoNow all the agreed work has been done and the path is looking fantastic.Peter Matthews, Walker Group managing director, said: ldquoWersquove worked hard to deliver a well-designed place to be enjoyed by families who live in the Long Meadow development and the wider village.ldquoAs part of our agreement with the council, we provided funds to ensure the path which runs along the side of the development was upgraded.ldquoAs a responsible developer, as well as delivering high-quality developments for our customers, wersquore committed to providing opportunities to enhance the local area and contribute investment to benefit surrounding communities.

title: traditional-tents-replaced-wooden-cabins-holiday-campsite
story: Scripture Union Scotland has been running camping holidays at Scoughall Farm, east of North Berwick, since the early s.Now, changes to the campsite will see five wooden cabins, as well as a pod, put in place of the tents.The charity, which uses the site from March through to October, runs ldquomulti-activity, resident events for young people.It said: ldquoThis change will enable us to meet the changing expectations of young people without departing from the historical style of the campsite.ldquoThe new buildings will be located in the same area as the tents were pitched and will allow the site to be used to its full potential throughout the season.ldquoThere is no plan to increase the capacity of the site or theof the season.ldquoThe buildings will be supplied with electricity by linking to the on-site supply or from small inidual solar units attached to each building ndash there will be no other utilities supplied.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department approved the proposals last week, with no members of the public objecting to the scheme.The local authority imposed two conditions: that the accommodation can be used only from March to October, and only by Scripture Union Scotland or an organisation on its behalf.

title: order-free-lateral-flow-covid-test-scotland
story: People can order test packages online for home delivery by following details on the Scottish Governmentrsquos website.Alternatively, the nose and throat swab tests can be collected from covid testing centres in the afternoons or early evening.Heres what you need to know:A negative lateral flow test that I took today.You can order free packs of rapid lateral flow tests to be sent to your homeyou live in Scotland, are over  and:There are dferent tests you can get to checkyou have coronavirus . The test you need depends on why youre getting tested.The twomain tests are:Both tests are free.A rapid lateral flow testpack contains seventests.You can only order one pack per household each day.You can order a test here.If you have someone on the shielding list in your household or are planning to travel to a Scottish island, select yes when the site asksyou were asked to get tested by a local authority or by an NHS Public Health team.For those travelling to a Scottish island, they should also click Scotland under the where in the UK do you live question, eventhey live in England, Wales or Northern Ireland.Results will be displayed on the handheld device which comes with the test - heres what they mean:You must self-isolate immediately to prevent any further transmission.What a positive test looks like.Chief Medical Officer Dr Gregor Smith explained: "This expansion builds on our existing testing strategy, and will help our efforts to ease the country out of lockdown safely."Routine testing is already available for people with no symptoms in a wide range of settings, including schools, high-risk workplaces, and communities where Covid- rates remain stubbornly high."Rapid lateral flow testing is already helping us to find cases that might otherwise have been missed, as around one in three people with Covid- do not show symptoms."Thats why its vital people can access testing, eventhey dont feel unwell. It will help protect the people around you, and help us avoid anotherto lockdown."It may be tempting to think as vaccinations increase and cases drop, that testing will become less important."In fact, this will only make it more important to spot and prevent new outbreaks as cases emerge."We know from our experience of last summer just how quickly one outbreak can lead to another."This also applies regardless of whether you have been vaccinated or not."While the latest evidence suggests vaccines provide a high level of protection against the effects of Covid-, they dont yet provide a guarantee that you cant still get the virus or pass it on to others."Follow these stepsyoursquore doing a rapid LFD test at home.Ifyou do not have coronavirus symptoms but live in a community that has been targeted for testing, you can access a test at a rapid test site.These are only available in some parts of Scotland.You can usually just turn up and do not need to book in advance ndash but you should check the arrangements at your local site first.You will be tested using a lateral flow devicewhich involves taking a swab or saliva sample.You should usually get your result within an hour.The First Minister also added that people visiting the islands should take two lateral flow tests before travelling.Nicola Sturgeon said: "We are keeping island communities at the same level as the rest of the country at the moment, so that we can allow travel between island communities and the rest of Scotland."But we know this does create a risk for our island communities."Many of them currently have very, very low rates of Covid."And they will be welcoming visitors from parts of Scotland which I know many of them are looking forward to where Covid will still be circulating at a higher level and more widely."So If you are planning to travel to an island we do encourage you to take two lateral flow tests before you depart."The second test should be on the day that you are planning to travel, and the first should be three days before you travel."That means thatyou test positive, you have a chance to take a PCR test - which is more sensitive - to confirm the result before making a final decision on cancelling your visit."This is potentially an important way in which we can minimise the risk, of bringing Covid into island communities while nevertheless allowing our island communities the benefit of opening up again to visitors."Soyou are planning on travelling to an island over the course of next week, it is possible to get tests from today, and I would encourage you to do that."

title: covid-vaccine-passport-scheme-announced-scotland
story: Those who have been vaccinated can download a letter from the NHS Inform patient website, or request a letter from the Covid Status Helplinethey are not online.But as details of the vaccination status scheme were announced, Scotlandrsquos Chief Medical Officer Dr Gregor Smith urged people to be "highly cautious about international travel"and ldquocontinue to limit their travel abroad.Only those travelling to a country where proof of vaccination is needed as an entry requirement should request a letter.There are currently no countries that require travellers to show their vaccination status, but the letter scheme is being introduced because international travel requirements can change quickly during the pandemic.If yoursquore planning to travel abroad, you must:Countries may move between the green, amber and red lists at short notice.You should not assume that a country on the green, amber or red list now will remain on the same list over the weeks and months ahead.Before you travelYoull also need to:While in Scotland, you must at all times follow therules on Covid-.Testing while isolating in your hotelWhile staying in your hotel, youll need to take a Covid- test on day twoand day eightof your  day stay. These tests will be delivered to you at your hotel.If either of these tests are positive for COVID-, you may need to quarantine at your hotel for longer than  days.The cost of isolating in a hotelTo isolate in a hotel, youll need to pay:Theres no charge for children under .If you need to stay longer than  days because youa positive Covid- test, or because you have been told you are a close contact of someone who has tested positive, you must book extra days through theCTM booking portal.There will be no charge for these extra days.If you have been in a country or area on the red list at any point in the  days before arriving in Scotland, you will only be allowed to enter theUK either:You should not travel to red list countries or areas on holiday, or for any leisure purposes.Before travelling to Scotland from a red list country, yoursquoll need to:On arrival in Scotland,you mustquarantine in the hotel yoursquove booked for  days. If you test positive for Covid- while in quarantine, you may need to quarantine for longer.If yoursquove been in an amber list country in the  days before travelling to Scotland, you must:On arrival in Scotland you must:Before travelling to Scotland from a green list country or area, you must:You will not need to isolate unless:the result of the Covid- test yoursquove taken on day twoafter arriving back in Scotland is positiveThe Scottish Government said it hopes allowing people to download their own documents will ease the burden on the NHS, as travellers will not need to ask their GP for a letter.As the vaccination programme progresses, digital Covid Status Certicates, which will include vaccination and testing data, will be brought in for international travel.Dr Smith said: "Given the risk of ing with infection, and especially of introducing new iants of the virus, we continue to be highly cautious about international travel."Everyone should continue to limit their travel abroad and while I understand the need for some people who want to reunite with family, when it comes to holidays my advice continues to be play it safe and staycation this summer."For those that do need it, this new service will provide people with a record of their vaccination status for outbound international travel."They should only access their recordthey are planning to travel within  days and it is a requirement of their destination."

title: weekly-collections-coming-part-major-changes-recycling-east-lothian
story: Currently, households in East Lothian have green and blue recycling boxes which are collected once a fortnight, with plastic, glass and cans sorted into the green box and paper, card and cardboard into the blue box.However, from August, residents will see their collections increase in frequency to once every week, but will be tasked with sorting their recycling into four piles rather than two.The four separate streams are: plastics, cans and cartons glass bottles and jars paper and card and cardboard.Paper and card will continue to be collected in the existing blue boxes, with cardboard to either be sorted into a separate blue box or flattened and presented beside the boxes or in another cardboard box.Glass bottles and jars will continue to be collected in the existing green box, although these will be replaced with new black boxes in the future.Plastics, cans and cartons will be collected in a new container, which East Lothian Council describes as a ldquosealable, weighted, reusable bag.An East Lothian Council spokeswoman said: ldquoThe bag capacity is larger than the existing green boxes, can be self-sealed ndash so no need to attach a cover ndash and the bags are weighted to help prevent these lighter materials blowing away.The change will also coincide with the rollout of new collection vehicles which will pick up recycling and food waste at the same time.The council spokeswoman explained the reasons behind the changes.She said: ldquoIn , East Lothian Council became signatories to the Scottish Governmentrsquos Household Waste Charter, which aims to have all councils in Scotland collecting glass separate from plastic and cans, and cardboard and paper separate to the other materials.ldquoAs part of our commitment to both the charter and to tackling the climate emergency, we are changing our recycling services to a charter-aligned collection model that delivers best value through theof high-quality resources to the commodities market, while at the same time reducing the carbon impact of our waste and recycling services.ldquoFrom August, the collections will be carried out using specially designed resource recovery vehicles that can collect all the dferent materials and the food waste at the same time every week, reducing the number of times we have to visit each street by a third every year.She added that the move to weekly collections ldquoshould mean that many residents will store and present fewer containers than they currently do with the fortnightly service.The planned changes have been revealed after a multi-million-pound contract was signed to see a new company collect East Lothianrsquos recycling and food waste.FCC Environmentrsquos contract with East Lothian Council began on May  and will run until March .A new contract to collect East Lothianrsquos recycling and food waste has been signed. title: pub-owners-managers-east-lothian-delighted-welcome-back-customers-week

story: A DISTRESSING story made the front page of the East Lothian Courier on May , .Cruel-hearted teenagers are using baby birds on the River Tyne at Haddington for target practice, it was claimed this week.Week-old ducklings have been shot and a family of moorhens almost wiped out by youngsters armed with airguns.Community councillors and police have made a joint plea to those responsible to stop what they are doing or face being charged with a criminal offence following concern from townsfolk.The problem was discussed at the monthly meeting of Haddington and District Community Council on Tuesday.Councillor David Motherwell, a local environmentalist, who lives near the river, said nature took its toll on the young birds which were attacked by gulls and crows.But he had been approached by worried townsfolk who claimed teenagers as young as  were using the Nungate Bridge as a vantage point to shoot wildle.A BOMB scare at a North Berwick hotel made headlines in The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .Twenty-two residents at the Royal Hunting Lodge hotel slept on in the early hours of Thursday last unaware that police were searching the premises for a bomb.The night porter, Mr Robert Mackintosh, had received an anonymous telephone call at about . a.m. and a manrsquos voice said there was a bomb in the hotel.A similar call was also received by North Berwick Police.A thorough search was made of the hotel and grounds but no trace of a bomb was found.The call has been classed as a hoax.A WOMAN appeared in court charged with fraud, as reported in The Haddingtonshire Courier on May , .On Monday, in Haddington Sherf Court, Mary Power or Walker, we of an Ormiston miner, came up for sentence in a charge of defrauding the Tranent Co-operative Society by making a fictitious title: mary-contini-column-a-tsunami-infections-youth-unless-vaccine-rollout-speeds
story: With vision and endurance, they sowed the inspiration that has resulted in a unique market of excellent tourism, food production and export that has shone a spotlight on Scotlandrsquos incredible natural larder.We have all benefited: businesses, customers, visitors and not least the tax man, as the industry contributes millions to the public purse and provides employment of upwards of eight per cent of the population.In over a year of crippling Covid restrictions, our trade has been severely impacted. Many businesses have been left so much in debt they are on the edge of collapse.Now, as the longed-for hope to reopen fully lies tantalisingly ahead, the very real threat of a new, more virulent iant virus has been identied.As hotels, pubs and restaurants are opening our doors, our teams now face a daily, hourly threat of infection from an innocent, unwitting carrier of this dangerous infection.This is not a horror movie. This is real le!Amazingly,  per cent of Scots over  have had their first, lesaving vaccination and as many as  per cent are fully protected with their second jab.The over-s in the population are thankfully next on the list.However, of the youngest cohort, --year-olds, less than  per cent have had a first vaccination.Hospitality is staffed by the highest proportion of young people in the country and, as they are now unprotected and working in a more relaxed environment, they are most vulnerable to infection.So, a plea to Government. Please move into emergency mode. Increase the pace of vaccination, pull out all the stops and get the stockpiles of lesaving elixir into our young peoplersquos arms. They are ready to roll up their sleeves. They want and deserve to be protected.The alternative ndash a tsunami of Covid infection in our youth ndash is not even worth considering.

title: dave-berry-column-east-lothian-political-bellwether
story: Not only was it the only Labour seat to fall to the SNP at this monthrsquos election, but both second and third-place candidates became MSPs by dint of their high places on party lists for South Scotland.Despite proximity to Edinburgh, we have tended to be overlooked. Now, having three MSPs of parties totalling over  per cent of Holyrood, our voice should be stronger.On the other hand, the county can also be seen as a bellwether of national trends extending well beyond Scotland. From trends here, both the new make-up of the Scottish Parliament and the drubbing Labour received in the Hartlepool by-election could have been anticipated.Once,  years of Tory policies had made Scotland grumpy. A phalanx of Labour MPs were shown powerless to deflect this.Blairrsquos  landslide came by appealing to a new middle class and assumingthat Old Labour voters had nowhere  to go. Scotland was Old Labour, based around town hall bastions and minersrsquo welfares, rooted ndash as East Lothian ndash in former coalfields and heavy industries.Growth of affluence from the s onward created a new demographic sht towards the middle class. Edinburghrsquos spilled into East Lothian: West Windygoul and Sandersonrsquos Wynd in Tranent Appin Dive and Suthren Yett in Prestonpans. These new residents rarely voted Labour, let alone lsquokent his faitherrsquo.Conservatives, driven back to bastions like Gullane Hill, failed to exploit this. Local-focused campaigns by Lib Dems and SNP did and seized control of East Lothian Council.This pattern was repeated across central Scotland, decimating Labourrsquos lsquopayrollrsquo army of campaign workers, drawn from councillors and MP MSP staff.This let a buoyant SNP work lsquoLabour heartlandsrsquo with social democratic policies, leading to the  SNP landslide to a supposedly impossible Holyrood majority, from which Labour has yet to recover. Even the Tories, decimated and disheartened two decades ago, worked their way back into second place under Ruth Davidsonrsquos leadership.It appears lessons from Hartlepool have not been learned by Labour. Their lsquoRed Wallrsquo remains on course to follow Tranent and Haddington Labour Clubs and become red rubble.

title: east-lothian-council-extension-big
story: The proposed extension to a cottage atGarleton, near Haddington, was rejected because East Lothian planners ruled it was bigger than the original building.However, their claim it was the same as building another house in the countryside, which goes against council policy, has been thrown out by councillors on appeal.A virtual meeting of the councilrsquos Local Review Body saw an appeal by the homeowners upheld after members said they were ldquocomfortable with the extension.The original plans to extend Nouster Cottage were, agents for the owners said, to allow an inter-generational family to live together at the property.The single-storey cottage, which had already had extensions added over the years, would have a new one and a half-storey extension including a boot room, hallway, playroom, snooker room and three bedrooms, and would add eight new rooms and two bathrooms to the three-bedroom cottage.But while planners described the extension as bigger than the house, agents APT Planning said that once outbuildings and a conservatory due to be demolished as part of the work were taken into account, it only made up a third of the cottagersquos footprint.They told the review body: ldquoWe strongly refute the conclusion that this is effectively a new house in the countryside, it very clearly is not.No objections to the plans were lodged but there were letters of support for the family.The agents said that the family bought the cottageto accommodate their growing multi-generational family.They added: ldquoThe family has two young boys and also an ageing parent with a degenerative disease.ldquoTheaccommodation has been designed with the three generations of family in mind, blending the needs of young and old and so that the grandparent can live comfortably on the ground floor .The review body agreed to uphold the appeal against the decision to refuse permission for the extension.Councillor John Williamson said: ldquoIt is an existingproperty being extended and I am comfortable approving it.Fellow review body member Jeremy Findlay agreed, along with convenorCouncillor John McMillan.A condition to replace or retain some trees which might be affected by the build was included and councillors also asked that a garage planned as part of the extension should have a condition stopping it from being used as additional accommodation.Councillor Findlay added: ldquoWe have had incidents in Gullane where people have built garages then surreptitiously added a room or two, so I feel strongly about this condition.

title: east-lothian-food-drink-businesses-vote-whether-continue-business-improvement-district
story: First created in , East Lothian Food  Drink Business Improvement District, in partnership with East Lothian Council and Queen Margaret University, has worked to promote East Lothian food and drink businesses.By creating a unying voice and marketing East Lothian as a quality provider of outstanding produce, the sector has benefited from a range of initiatives from direct selling to attendance at events and the creation of a digital marketing .Now, eligible businesses have the opportunity to vote on a second term and to continue to work together and drive the rebuilding of the food and drink sector in East Lothian following the impacts of recent lockdowns, stay-at-home orders and physical distancing.BIDs in Scotland have traditionally been focused on urban high streets, encompassing a number of dferent businesses. The East Lothian Food  Drink BID pioneered a new type of BID involving a single sector with a wider geographical area it remains the only food and drink sector BID in Scotland.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Provost, said: ldquoThe initial five years has seen many highlights and Scotlandrsquos Food  Drink County is fast becoming a highly visible brand.ldquoFrom member feedback, we know that working in this collaborative way is bringing real benefits.ldquoI would urge all eligible local businesses to vote to continue this fantastic collaboration for another five years.East Lothian Council has committed to continued financial support of the BIDthe vote to continue for a further five years is successful.It will also continue to provide expertise through membership of the board and the support of the economic development team.Chris Luca, chair of East Lothian Food  Drink, said: ldquoAs a local food and drink producer, the East Lothian Food  Drink BID has provided us with a great opportunity to work together and make the changes we as a sector want.

story: The First Minister has confirmed that Moray will move to Level  from midnight tonight, Glasgow City will remain in Level  for at least a further week and East Renfrewshire will stay in Level  - but they need a bit longer to do that."We also need a bit more time to be confident than we are now that vaccination will stop the rising case numbers today becoming severe illness and sharply rising hospital numbers a couple of weeks from now."So for all these reasons, I can confirm today that regrettably, Glasgow will remain in Level  for another week at this stage."I know, not least because I live in Glasgow myself, how unwelcome this is for iniduals and businesses - because its a smaller area, obviously - is signicantly smaller than in Glasgow."To illustrate that, yesterday there were actually just  new cases reported in East Renfrewshire - compared to  in Glasgow. More importantly, many more of the cases in East Renfrewshire can be traced to specic household clusters, unlike in Glasgow."That means that we think strong and targeted public health measures have more of a chance of stemming the rise in East Renfrewshire, without the need to use wider restrictions."Taking all of that into account, our judgement - and these decisions are often finely balanced - is that East Renfrewshire should stay at Level  for now, although this will be kept under close review and well continue to use enhanced public health measures."Nicola Sturgeon confirmed that Moray will move to Level  from midnight tonight.Ms Sturgeon said: "Im very pleased to say that the situation has actually improved very signicantly."Last week, the area was reporting  new cases a week per , - story: The measures have evolved from the Musselburgh Active Travel Network Masterplan produced in .This identied six key active travel routes aimed at encouraging more people to get around the town without using a car.The masterplan, which resulted from previous consultation, received a ldquohigh level of support and further local connectors to the key routes have now been added to provide a complete network.The consultation will focus on outline design options for three key routes which run west to east, north of the town centre, and south to north from the new developments near Queen Margaret University and along the River Esk:Councillor Norman Hampshire, environment spokesperson, said: ldquoDue to current Covid restrictions, the initial consultation will be online and a specic project website has been created at musselburghactivetoun.infoldquoWe will also hold online discussions with stakeholders and community groups who the project team will contact over the next few weeks.ldquoWe hope to hold a number of events to engage with businesses, residents, community groups and schools as restrictions start to ease.ldquoDuring periods of lockdown, we know that many people have taken the opportunity to use methods of active travel more, with an increase in people choosing to walk or cycle more.ldquoFrom informal discussions, it appears that many local residents want to be able to continue to do so but in safer environments which we hope these key routes will provide.ldquoI would encourage people who live or work in Musselburgh to take the time to consider these proposals and to provide feedback that will help us shape the next stage. We want to ensure that the proposals make the best use of the street space.

title: musselburgh-couple-delighted-celebrate-diamond-wedding
story: John, from Fisherrow, known to his friends and colleagues as Ducky, worked in Bruntons Wiremill in Musselburgh, while June, from Gorgie, was a seamstress at Buchananrsquos in Edinburgh.They met at the dancing in the old Labour Hall which was situated above the police station on Musselburgh High Street.The week after, John, who entertains audiences by singing his favourite Scottish songs at parties and s, took June out on a date to the theatre to see Scottish singer Calum Kennedy.A fan of the works of Scotlandrsquos national poet Robert Burns, John, a past vice-president of the Newcraighall Poosie Nansie Burns Club, can recite the Bardrsquos works without looking at a book, much to the delight of his family, and is renowned for his talent in giving Address To A Haggis.Love blossomed for the couple and, after taking June on a date to the Wiremill centenary dance at the Stoneybank Institute, now the community centre, he asked her to marry him.Their wedding took place at Portobello Registry Office on May , , with Irene Dodds and George Hutchison as witnesses.The couple set up home at the Promenade in Musselburgh, where they lived until their family expanded, which saw them move to Galt Road ndash their home of  years.John worked with the electricity board based in Musselburgh for  years until he retired.He was an electrical fitter with ScottishPower, installing high-voltage switch gear in substations.June was a home help in the community for more than  years looking after the older generation.Prior to her retirement, she worked at Adamwood nursing home at Ravensheugh Road, Musselburgh.John, who is well known is fishing and shooting circles, also collected the football pools coupons for  years for Littlewoods pools.John, , and June, , have four children ndash John, Andrew, Kathleen and Margaret ndash  grandchildren and  great grandchildren.The couple enjoyed a low-key diamond wedding celebration at their Galt Road home amidst the Covid- pandemic, with family members attending at intervals to share a slice of cake and cup of tea.This is in contrast from their usual celebrations, which would always involve a large gathering of family and friends at a party with Scottish music and Johnrsquos favourite tipple, a wee dram of whisky.John and June were ldquoover the moon to receive a card from the Queen to mark the occasion, which was arranged by their daughters Kathleen and Margaret.The couple said that their recipe for a long and happy marriage was having ldquoa good close loving family around you, who love and care for you.June added that looking after John and all the dogs they had over the years gave her ldquomuch joy.

title: decision-plans-new-affordable-homes-dunbar-delayed

title: musselburgh-lollipop-man-john-mclay-praised-one-kind
story: Popular John McLay, , who mans a crossing at Pinkie Road, near Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, goes the extra mile by wearing lsquocool characterrsquo socks and festive hats, turning into Santa at Christmas and buying a bunch of flowers each Friday to give to someone in the street in a bid to brighten up their day.Parent Kirsty Clark, who runs the after-school club, said: ldquoHe really is one of a kind, a truly caring and lovely man. title: movies-returning-brunton-musselburgh-week
story: From Wednesday, the theatre will resume its big screen movies and event screenings in Venue , with modications to ensure comfort and safety in line with Scottish Government regulations. Staff will be on hand to welcome the public and answer questions.The film Nomadlandgets the programme going on Wednesday.The move is based on Jessica Bruderrsquos eponymous book, with a cast populated by real-le nomads playing fictional versions of themselves.From Oscar and BAFTA-winning director Chloe Zhao, this drama is a look at a rare way of le, full of quiet joy, generosity and humility, with a leading performance from the Oscar-winning Frances McDormand as Fern.Embarking on a journey through the American West, Fern stores all her worldly possessions and begins a simpler existence in her kitted-out van on the road. Though Fern must adapt to the trials and pains of nomad le, she also finds a sense of community in the open road, the wizened, expansive landscapes and her dedicated compatriots.Then, Ammonitewill be screened on Wednesday, June .Set on the Dorset coastline, British filmmaker Francis Leeexplores the le of British palaeontologist Mary Anning in this period romance starring Kate Winslet and Saoirse Ronan.Anningrsquos talented but often overlooked career as a fossil hunter has left her walking the shorelines alone. title: josh-taylors-fiancee-danielle-murphy-ecstatic-win---hoping-start-wedding-planning
story: Danielle Murphy watched the fight from home in Haddington after Covid- restrictions prevented her from flying to Las Vegas.Josh, from Prestonpans, beat his American rival with a unanimous points victory to become the undisputed super lightweight world champion.: Josh Taylor crowned undisputed world championDanielle told the Courier: ldquoI am absolutely ecstatic about his win, he has made history."All the hard work, dedication and years that he has put into his craft have paid off.ldquoI was gutted not to fly over, there have been other times when he has gone away and we havenrsquot been able to be there but with the magnitude of this fight, everyone wanted to be there to support him, but we were all cheering him on and screaming for him at the television.Danielle said the Taylor family are excited to celebrate when the world champion touches down in Scotland today , but Covid- restrictions are making it dficult.She said: ldquoWe are having to play it by ear because it is hard to book anything."Normally we would go into a hall or celebrate in a pub but there are only so many people you can have in aand there is no way you could only pick  people to celebrate, so we arenrsquot doing that.ldquoWe are hoping to be able to get an open-top bus for him, but we need to seethe council will allow that.Danielle was disappointed by the lack of national televised coverage of the fight.She said: ldquoIt is absolutely shocking that the fight wasnrsquot broadcast on a bigger  for others to be able to watch.ldquoThe older generation do not have smartphones, so they were struggling to watch it when it was on because it was streamed through an app."Danielle said Josh was flying home on Tuesday for some well-deserved time off.The couple got engaged in Dubai last December.Danielle said: "Hopefully he can take some time off so we can get our wedding planned and chill for a while."

title: food-give-dessert-attention-deserves-new-cookbooks
story: Come summer, barbecues seem to snag all the glory, but really, its the season when sweet things can take on new brilliance and importance.After all, what is a hot, golden July day without a Twister lolly melting down your wrist  Can you get more sophisticated than affogatoin August  And what can beat the chewy, creamy crunch of Eton mess and gooseberry fool on a June evening However,your summer pudding game tends to lean solely towards ice pops and strawberries and cream, find inspiration in these new cookbooks dedicated to dessert...Gelupo Gelato by Jacob Kenedy - available May Chef and restaurateur Jacob Kenedys new book is a witty, compact, highly enthusiastic ode to all things gelato. Free of pictures, its illustrated boldly in a manner that alleviates the pressure to make ice cream parlour-worthy peaks at home - you can just have fun and experiment instead. The simplicity of the recipes makes it rather child-friendly too.Most intriguing are Kenedys flavour combinations: liquorice, Aperol, ricotta, black pepper and chocolate, apple strudel, lemon and rosemary - his concoctions are the ice cream equivalent of Farrow and Ball tones. Picking just one is near impossible. Its not just gelato he celebrates either, but sundaes and ice cream cakes, granita and sorbets. Clear the freezer now.Wild Sweetness by Thalia HoThere is a sense of the ethereal to Butter and Brioche blogger Thalia Hos writings and recipes. She makes you recall childhood ramblings scratching your arms on blackberry brambles and getting the red juice of strawberries all over your clothes and face while illicitly eating your pick your own haul, long before you reached the till.Nature, its sweetness and bounty, defines her new cookbook, which mirrors the seasons and what can be snaffled and when. Theres a freshness to her dishes too. Have you ever tried juniper and white chocolate ice cream  Or parsnip cake with tahini frosting  The books muted palette also feels very elegant, very grown up despite the nostalgia that seeps from the pages.Peggy Porschen: A Year in Cake - available June Sometimes - even on a hot summers day - a huge slice of cake is the only thing that will do. Fortunately, Peggy Porschen has you absolutely covered. Admittedly, her creations are as pink and frothy as her London bakeries , but dont let that distract from the decadent summer berry cupcakes, lemon elderflower tartlets and ombre cherry and chocolate cake.If pudding for you is exquisitely detailed, highly iced and decorated to the hilt, youll find this quite heavenly.La Vita e Dolce by Letitia Clark - available June If you follow chef Letitia Clark on Instagram, youll be familiar with the pangs of longing her Cezanne-like shots of fresh picked lemons, Mediterranean sunsets and technicolor salads of burrata, fennel and blood orange. British-born, Clark now lives in Sardinia, but she dampens the envy her le can induce by sharing it - especially the food. And oh, does the food look incredible.While her  debut cookbook, Bitter Orange, captured the crisp fried delicacies of the Italian island, as well as its wonderful dependency on olive oil and all the cheese , La Vita e Dolce zones in on nutty biscotti, tarts that sing with fruit, Campari spiked tortes and panna cotta galore. The Italians know their sweet stuff, and Clark has extracted all the goodness for us.

title: long-lost-family-born-without-trace
story: Long Lost Family: Born Without Trace.Tell me more.Davina McCall and Nicky Campbell delve into the remarkable stories of foundlings ndash those who were abandoned as babies, often in the first hours or days of their lives ndash as they attempt to discover more about their identities after a letime in the dark.Born without trace, with no birth record or name, those featured on the show have been unable to solve the mystery of their origins and, ultimately, who they are. title: herald-sunday-letters-uk-needs-devo-max-movement-save-us-years-fruitless-confusion-rancour
story: However there is hope. With Labour and the LibDems being seen as ldquolosers in the recent election, little attention is being given to the fact that their manestos contained proposals for a Constitutional Commission being established to come up with some form of practical federalism. North of the Border we talk of Devo Max. Without a third option a repeat of the binary Yes No in indyref could lead to disaster with no lessons having been learned from the politics of ision of the past five years.:Lord Advocate James Wolffe to step down within daysIn this context I was much encouraged by Andy Maciverrsquos article Scotland away ... and how to stop doing it, May  and by Gavin Eslerrsquos splendid book How Britain Ends: English Nationalism and the Rebirth of Four Nations.Both Mr Maciverrsquos and Mr Eslerrsquos approach can be summed up by Mr Maciverrsquos assertion that ldquounionists must reimagine unionism. The only viable United Kingdom, now, is a looser kingdom at ease with its many identities and embracing its political ersity and by Mr Eslerrsquos ldquoHome Rule for All Nations will not be easy. But it is probably the last chance of saving the many good things about our United Kingdom, building upon the UKrsquos existing quasi-federal structure being the obvious way to proceed.Furthermore a reading of both reveals that the more rational Scottish nationalists recognise that in this day and age there can be no ldquoabsolute independence and as a consequence it is not entirely inconceivable that they and the ldquofederalists may not be so far apart when it comes to the crunch, the minorities of ultra unionists and Scottish nationalists being the only opposition to the achievement of a reasonable solution.And so the UK needs a Devo Max movement, the core of which is surely to be found in the Labour Party ldquowith Sir Keir Starmerrsquos idea of a constitutional convention being a reasonable first step , as Mr Esler suggests.John Milne, Uddingston.WHY SHOULD WE JUMP OFF A CLIFF NICOLA Sturgeon rightly said in her acceptance speech on re-election as First Minister, that those of who do not support independence cannot be ldquobludgeoned towards an outcome you have not been persuaded of.:Iain Macwhirter: Time to cancel university bosses who violate laws on free speechWith those words the First Minister sums up how it has felt living over the last many years in Scotland, for those who value what we share with our fellow citizens across the UK.Day in, day out, the heavy hand of Scottish nationalism has made its presence felt, badly mismanaging critical public services like education, whilst simultaneously seeking to impose a ldquowe-know-best attitude into many aspects of our lives. All the while, the SNP leadership has used every opportunity to stir grievance against the UK, promoting ision rather than recognising the benefits of working positively together.Despite warm-sounding political spin, the First Ministerrsquos acceptance speech reasserts the SNPrsquos determination to impose its will on the half of Scotland who oppose it. Meanwhile, we have no hint of clarity or honesty on reasonable concerns over the challenges the SNPrsquos overriding objective will likely mean for us.As some countries look forward to enjoying a period of calm normality once they emerge from the awful effects of Covid, our First Minister instead offers us a vision of ision and uncertainty. Using her own favourite Brexit imagery, she appears to want Scotland to join hands with her and jump off a clf into the unknown, simply because she says we should.Keith Howell, West Linton.FIGURES SHOW WERE NECK AND NECKGERALD Edwardspresents the tired old contention that the SNP ldquoonly secured  per cent of the ldquoavailable constituency vote. Of course, what he means is that ldquoonly % of registered electors voted SNP in their constituency. However, readers might care to note that on the same basis the Conservative vote was .% of the ldquoavailable constituency vote and Labourrsquos .%. How a voting system works has a clue in its name ndash ldquovoting. One must register a vote to register an opinion.Moreover, itrsquos interesting that he uses the constituency vote to claim that the unionist vote was higher than the independence vote. Using the list vote instead and removing votes for parties with no explicit manesto position on independence , which amounted to .% of the total votes cast, the proportion of votes for parties explicitly supporting independence was .% of votes cast, compared to .% for anti-independence parties.Any dispassionate view of these figures could only conclude that the independence and unionist sides are, currently neck and neck. Statistical sophistry of the kind initiated by your correspondent does little to take forward any debate. Perhaps, this might have something to do with the fact that at the start of the last referendum debate, independence started on something like %  Could it be this is another part of the unionist campaign to talk down another referendum and the possibility of independence by bogus means, and thus avoid defeat Alasdair Galloway, Dumbarton.DIFFERENCE BETWEEN CLIMATE AND WEATHERI NOTE Clark Crosss letter , in which he says: "Every time there is an unusual weather event the green brigade rush to say it is climate change" and wish to respond. Pete Townshend wrote: ldquoThe simple things you see are all complicated.This perfectly describes atmospheric processes.The basics are simple. Earthrsquos atmosphere is absorbing and retaining more solar energy as this is trapped by greenhouse gases. This energy is either dissipated or stored in a iety of ways, with dferent outcomes, all governed by basic physical processes. The atmosphere behaves in line with the combined gas laws. Pressure, volume and temperature constantly interact.Kinetic is movement energy, of both wind and water. More atmospheric energy will mean more wind, bigger waves, and even faster or disrupted flows of ocean currents. A present benefit to us is that the Forth and Clyde are not icebound in winter.More kinetic energy means peak events like hurricanes are likely to be more powerful.Storm energy can be dissipated in electric storms like thundersnow, once rare, now frequent.Both atmosphere and oceans may absorb more heat energy, so temperatures rise.Warmer oceans hold more dissolved gases, becoming more acid. This can have a dramatic effect on marine lersquos ability to survive, corals being a sensitive le form. Corals store carbonates in their reefs. This is a knock-on impact. Fewer corals means less take-up of carbon. These feedback loops intensy climate change impacts.Warmer air in higher latitudes and altitudes will melt more polar and glacier ice. Oceanic thermal expansion will also cause sea level rise,it is not sea ice.The albedo effect ndash reflectivity ndash complicates ice loss impacts. Open sea, formerly ice-covered, absorbs more heat energy than highly reflective ice floes, thus allowing more rapid heat transfers in high latitude oceans. This then accelerates further ice melt.Another basic physical process ndash latent heat, or conversion energy, governs the melting of ice into water . Ice melting, in huge masses, requires a much larger energy transfer than just raising it from -C to C.Mass transfers of energy are needed to drive the hydrological cycle. Water vapour evaporates from the seas, condenses into clouds, then rain or snow.More energy can mean higher rain or snowfall. Additional cloud cover reflects more solar energy so we also have to account for a mitigating impact.Yet, some large air masses stall and produce longer periods of stable drier or hotter weather leading to droughts, and increased fire risk, especially in Mediterranean climates.These are all energy transfers. Feedback loops within these systems then either accelerate or slow processes. It isnrsquot a neat linear progression.Climate is the average weather over a -year cycle. Single weeks, months, even years can erge from the overall direction of longer term trends. Such is "bias" or "noise". No atmospheric scientist will say any single peak event is definitely caused by climate change. Yet over time more storms and powerful weather events are likely.One of the problems of climate change is that fish donrsquot see water. Wersquore immersed in daily weather patterns so the bigger picture is often concealed.Mr Crossrsquos piscine observations are one such example.Tony Philpin, Gigha.LOCKDOWNS ARE NOT THE ANSWERGLASGOW is facing a lockdown extension . But there are many scientic studies that cast doubt on the efficacy of lockdowns. For example, in December a Korean team led by S Hong published a study which says that, except for school closures and contact tracing, all non-clinical Covid measures ldquoare proven to be statistically insignicant or even have a negative impact.A Stanford team led by E Bendavid published a paper in January which says ldquothere is no evidence that more restrictive nonpharmaceutical interventionscontributed substantially to bending the curve of new cases in England, France, Germany, Iran, Italy, the Netherlands, Spain or the US in early .And in February a Canadian study published by A Joffe says that the recession and austerity resulting from government lockdowns ldquocan be expected to cause far more loss of le and well-being over the long run than Covid- can.Government ministers and advisors should be askedtheyre willing to forego their salaries for the duration of any lockdown.Geoff Moore, Alness.BBC SHOULD AXE QUESTION TIMERON McKays comments on Question Timehit the mark. The programme is a travesty of its former self, even allowing for restrictions caused by the pandemic. The "virtual" audience are "virtually" the same every week. Their contributions are predictable. There is no meaningful debate. How are these people chosen, week on week  Fiona Bruce does not even ask viewers now to volunteer for future programmes.If this is the best the BBC can do the programme should be axed, until something more like its original format can be re-instated.Sandra MacDougall, Edinburgh.

title: deck-downton-abbey-meets-game-thrones
story: Or, as one story in Tatler puts it, ldquoa wave of affluent buyers looking to escape lockdown misery snap up their own floating palaces. How the other half live, eh My fascination with motor yachts, though, is largely stoked by the fact I have been binge-watching a reality TV series called Below Deck. The show follows a motley yacht crew as they toil at the beck-and-call of uber-rich clients with eye-watering demands.It is not for the faint-hearted, with the premise best described as Downton Abbey meets Keeping Up With The Kardashians with a dash of Game of Thrones.After each charter,all goes well, the staff below stairs get a huge tip from the guests ndash then swtly splash this hard-earned cash by getting legless at swanky beach and island resorts dotted across the Caribbean and Mediterranean.There are drunken spats and messy dramas and simmering feuds and dastardly power plays that will make you gasp at their audacity. It is terribly gauche yet gloriously compelling viewing.:Susan Swarbrickrsquos Week: A semblance of normality looms ndash why donrsquot I feel ready I say this because I have devoured  episodes of Below Deck Mediterranean. I am now three series into Below Deck .Mastermind, here I come. My specialist subject: the trials and tribulations of chief stewardesses Kate Chastain and Hannah Ferrier on Below Deck. These women embody ingenuity and tenacity. They are nails.To be honest, Irsquove always envied those with the robust constitution that makes a good sailor. Over the years, I have been seasick on the Atlantic, Pacic and Indian oceans, as well as the Adriatic, Coral, South China, Red, North, Mediterranean and Tasman seas. It is hard to choose my most embarrassing debacle in this vein.Arguably, it is a toss-up between when I became queasy on a pedalo on Loch Lomond and had to be towed to shore as small children pointed in horried amusement as my pallor veered between ghostly grey and pistachio green.Or perhaps the shark-ing excursion in South Africa where I misjudged the direction of the wind and inadvertently acquainted a poor German chap dozing on the deck with the remnants of my breakfast.To this day, I still marvel at how calm and polite he was ndash even when the smell from his soggy fleece pervaded the minibus all the way back to Cape Town.:Susan Swarbricks Week: Help! I have a serious dose of vaccine envyI have crossed the North Atlantic on QE during a force  storm, a torrid experience that saw me spend the best part of two days hugging the toilet in my cabin like I was Kate Winslet clinging to that floating shard of wood in the film Titanic.So, the question remains: would I buy a big fancy boat. Probably not. But you donrsquot need sea legs to dream on the sofa.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald
